Liquid, soft foods after dental work.

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎06-06-2013 02:45 PM

I had a tooth extracted yesterday and wondered if anyone had a good idea for food that isnt's crunchy or chewey. I had a scrambled egg for breakast. I have tons of my salad fixings but all that greenery usually sticks to my teeth a little and I want to wait a few days before my salad stuff. I am going to have more dental work too.

I don't have a blender to make smoothie type meals. Any ideas?

How about cottage cheese, yogurt, small portion of mashed beans, mashed cauliflower, avocado, canned tuna.
Ruth

‎06-06-2013 07:21 PM

It might not be appetizing, but in this case, it might be a good idea to get out the good old trusty food processor and simply take whatever diabetic-friendly food you like to normally eat and process it into a paste, then eat it that way, until you can go back to eating normally.

 

I had to do this after they extracted two of my teeth.

 

For example, I cooked fresh broccoli in the microwave until it was fully cooked, then put it into the food processor and made it into a paste.  Then I could simply mix in a tiny amount of some cream cheese or sour cream, and I had a tasty meal out of it.

 

You could do the same thing with many veggies, or even things like steak, or salmon, etc.

 

Cook them normally, first, then process the heck out of them until they are a smooth paste, ready to slurp down.

 

.

I had a tooth extracted yesterday and wondered if anyone had a good idea for food that isnt's crunchy or chewey. I had a scrambled egg for breakast. I have tons of my salad fixings but all that greenery usually sticks to my teeth a little and I want to wait a few days before my salad stuff. I am going to have more dental work too.

I'm still recovering from a recent molar extraction. For the first week I had eggs in various forms, lots of soups and overcooked soft veges. I can now chew, but I try hard to favour the side away from the empty socket.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)

‎06-07-2013 04:10 AM

Gerber Squeezables are pouches with pureed vegetables and fruit in various combinations.  I discovered them last fall when Dawg had some surgery and needed to get more liquid nutrition in her food.  They now make them for grown-ups, too.  (Sorry, I don't remember the brand.)  And just today I saw something new at Target: Whipped Peanut Butter and Whipped Chocolate Peanut Butter in little tubs!  Refried beans, hummus, pureed tomatoes and spreadable/squeezable cheese were also on my list when I had a couple of wisdom teeth out several years ago.

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

Re: Liquid, soft foods after dental work.

‎06-07-2013 09:10 AM

I had a tooth implant done last summer where the old tooth with a root canal was ankylosed (fused) to the bone, thus they also had to remove all the bone in the front of the tooth to yank it out. Needless to say I couldn't eat solid food for over a month, maybe it was closer to 2 months. 

 

I went to the grocery store and just bought anything that looked easy to eat. 

 

I do have a hand blender thingy so did use that a bit. 

 

anyway, lots of soup, scrabled eggs, mashed up soft veggies (cauliflower (which also make an awesome pureed soup), carrots, etc), a lot of lentils, especially dal (the lentils without the shells) - cook em down, mash em up, good protein source. fish was far easier than meats. if you can do dairy, yogurt is good. I can't do dairy but eat coconut milk yogurt. I was actually surprised how many different kinds of foods I could eat. though being able to eat "solid" food again was nice. 

TikTok2

• Diabetes on both sides of my family.
• Assumed trouble metabolizing sugar as long as I can remember; migraines induced by hunger, very sleepy after meals high in carbohydrates from childhood. Learned how to avoid sugar and lots of complex carbs early on.
• Since early 2000s, "prediabetes" controlled through low carb diet and exercise, mostly walking. FBG 95-105, A1c below 6; glucose tolerance test was borderline.
• But weight drifted upwards but working on it.
• NAFLD brought under control with pravastatin.
• Metformin ER, 500 mg, started sept 2013 when A1c reached 6.5 despite diet and exercise regiment since early 2000s. A1c back down to ~6.0.

‎01-02-2014 08:32 AM

Take 4-5 glass of protein shake with out the sugar and if not possible then have skim milk  with some brown bread to go with it, if you have ever ate smash veggies with sugar free cream take that for dinner so that it would be a wholesome diet for the entire day and top of that if you want to avoid the veggies part then take 1 glass of milk add 2-3 spoon of natural honey not the artificial one which is available in the market consume this before going to bed it would give the needed energy.

‎01-02-2014 11:47 AM

meawlaade wrote:

Take 4-5 glass of protein shake with out the sugar and if not possible then have skim milk  with some brown bread to go with it, if you have ever ate smash veggies with sugar free cream take that for dinner so that it would be a wholesome diet for the entire day and top of that if you want to avoid the veggies part then take 1 glass of milk add 2-3 spoon of natural honey not the artificial one which is available in the market consume this before going to bed it would give the needed energy.

Navigate here.

Welcome to the community....do you have diabetes?  The suggestions you made would not work too well for many of us with diabetes.  Milk is high in carbohydrates and so is brown bread.  Drinking milk at 12 carbs per cup and 17.3 carbs per tablespoon of honey would, up being over 63 carbs close to the amount of carbs I eat in one day.  The link you left is to a site selling honey...are you connected to that site for profit or is it something you use for your diabetes care?  Solicitation is not allowed here on the ADA forums. 

 

Are you type 1 or type 2 diabetic?
